awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE: Software Tools for Biomolecular Free Energy Calculations
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Office of Cyberinfrastructure, Division of Materials Research, Chemistry Division, and Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation contribute funds to this award made on a proposal to the Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation solicitation.  This award supports the development of a new set of software tools for calculating biomolecular free energies, transition paths, and reaction rates that will be based on and will augment the PIs' ABMD/REMD/SMD suite of codes. New capabilities are to be added to the existing codes, which should greatly enhance the applicability of the software to challenging biomolecular problems. In particular, the PIs aim to implement and develop: (i) the capability for dealing with dynamically coupled multiple walkers or replicas for enhanced sampling; (ii) the introduction of Transition Path Theory and Sampling methodology for calculating reaction rates and related physical quantities; and (iii) the introduction of the "string method" for multi-dimensional free energy calculations and the calculation of the important minimum free energy path. These software tools will be released under the open source GPL, and released as part of the AMBER software package. The codes will also be released as stand-alone modules via the web for other users to integrate into their own programs.

To test and showcase the workings of the software package, the PIs will apply these methods to biomolecular systems where changes in handedness play an important role, including: proline-rich systems, mainly collagen and a new class of cell-penetrating peptides, and DNA and RNA in B and Z double helices. 

This award will also enhance education through: the mentoring and recruitment of minority students, the development of a Biophysics option, the integration of research topics into current educational forums, working with local schools, and the development of a new Institute for Computational Science and Engineering.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The Office of Cyberinfrastructure, Division of Materials Research, Chemistry Division, and Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation contribute funds to this award made on a proposal to the Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation solicitation.  This award supports the development of a new set of software tools that will enable the calculation of rates of chemical reactions involving biomolecules. The codes will also be able to calculate the energy that can be converted into useful work in a biochemical system. The codes will be distributed through a widely used software package called AMBER which contributes to the software cyberinfrastructure of computational chemistry, biochemistry, chemical engineering, materials, and biological physics communities. It will enable a wide range of computational research involving biological molecules. Among the possible applications are the study of the structure and transformations of biomolecules which provides information on their possible functions, the simulation of antibiotics, and simulating nanoscale technology applications. 

This award will also enhance education through: the mentoring and recruitment of minority students, the development of a Biophysics option, the integration of research topics into current educational forums, working with local schools, and the development of a new Institute for Computational Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The central role of atomistic free energy calculations for basic chemical and
biological research is now firmly established, as this is the central quantity
that determines the behavior of systems at or near equilibrium. For instance,
the free energy is the key quantity that predicts the delicate three-dimensional
structure of biomolecules, their binding, the chemical reactions they catalyze,
the molecular recognition problem, and the balance between different biological systems. Unfortunately, the free energy surfaces (FES) of most biomolecular systems are multi-dimensional, rough and often quite complex, so that very long time scales are typically needed to explore a given FES with any sort of reliability. This is generally precluded in regular molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, even under current parallel conditions. Given the central importance of this problem, considerable effort is currently being invested in developing and refining new free energy methods, which are especially tailored for complex FES when entropic contributions cannot be neglected.

This proposal was aimed at developing new software tools for calculation biomolecular energies, transition pathways and reaction rates. Our method is based on nonequilibrium, simulations, which estimate the free energy as a function of a set of collective variables from an evolving ensemble of realizations, and use that estiate to bias the system dynamics as to flatted the effective free energy surface. The method -- termed the Adaptively Biased Molecular Dynamics (ABMD) method -- is essentially an umbrella sampling method, in which the biasing force compensates for the free energy gradient
such that in the long-time limit, the biasing potential effectively reproduces the
negative of the unknown free energy surface. As part of this proposal, we introduced a number of enhancements to this method: (i) ABMD with a multiple walker selection algorithm -- Our original implementation of the multiple walker method was based on a set of non-interacting walkers or replicas. However, this can lead to potential problems because not all walkers are equally effective in sampling the configuration space. Often, these end up being ``bunched up" or clustered together in local metastable regions. For enhanced efficiency, one would like to encourage walkers that are wandering
in the under explored regions of phase space, and penalize walkers in the oversampled regions. To achieve this, we have implemented a selection mechanism that monitors the walkers on the fly, and updates them in a birth-death cycle so that all walkers remain effective samplers throughout the simulation. (ii) Well-tempered and driven ABMD -- We have implemented two additional algorithms that enhance the stability and convergence of the ABMD code. The first is termed the well-tempered ABMD makes use of a history dependent biasing potential that is updated at a ``well-tempered" rather than uniform rate as in the original implementation of ABMD. This modified way of updating the biasing potential leads to a smoother convergence to the desired free energy. The second method -- termed driven ABMD -- uses aspects of the Steered Molecular Dynamics (SMD) method (which is also part of the
ABMD software suite) for enhanced convergence and speedup.  (iii) Free energy method combined with Transition Path Sampling for reaction rate physics -- Reactions and transitions are an integral part of many physical, chemical and biological systems. However, their study is often hampered by the need to probe rare events, which are processes that occur on time scales that are beyond what is currently accessible by regular MD simulations. To help with this problem, we have developed a formalism based on combining Transition Path Theory with the nonequilibrium work theorem. This enables on
to calculate reaction rate probabilities and rates based on nonequilibrium SMD simulations.

The new ABMD package wth the new multiple walker selection algorithm and the well-tempered ABMD have been released to the public via the AMBER v.16 code.

In addition to the ABMD code developed, this proposal also involved a number of biomolecular simulation studies. These included (i) investigations of the B-to-Z DNA and RNA transitions; (ii) a comprehensive investigation of the distributions of ions around B- and Z-forms of DNA and RNA in a set of repeated CG dodecamers; (iii) simulations of the gp41HIV-1 antibody epitope, which was deemed to be a structurally challenging peptide; and (iv) investigations of the free energy and structural chacacteristics of proline-rich peptides with distributed multiple guests.

In terms of the broader impacts, we believe that the largest impact of this grant has been the generation of our free energy code released via AMBER. Aside from software, this research proposal has been instrumental in the education of graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow.
